review_title: Incompetent security leadership fit only to serve as warnings to others
pros:
Consistent Schedule
Usually good cohesion and teamwork with other rank and file security officers
Acceptable pay

If they are still there, you may have the privilege of working alongside some excellent men and women that deserve more recognition for the work they do. They shine all the brighter in contrast with the incompetence that is the Security department's leadership.
cons:
- incompetent leadership, little more than stubborn children who refuse to see what their actions cost them
- lackluster to absolutely pathetic responses to crises, the response that was implemented when the unfortunate incident on December 22nd, 2020 occurred was to request more officers from Metro Watch (a company that was contracted to supplement security officers to the location) the officers would be placed at each access point, wearing a high visibility vest, and nothing else in case 'something else happened', their response was to have unarmed, and unarmored officers at each entrance and thought that it was an adequate solution, it was not, none of the staff, especially the temp. checkers felt very safe
- security officers, as far as I am aware, are still unarmored, and not even equipped with Tasers, yet up in Longview at Peace Health St. John's (where the  head of security used to work) they have had tasers, and body armor without issue, yet these simpletons can't seem to find a way to justify this, despite the shooting at the 505 building
- incredible amount of tension between Metro Watch and Peace Health Southwest, most of the officers that showed up would be okay, but the three stooges seemed to take issue with anything and everything that Metro Watch did at the hospital, throwing officers under the bus for anything, and trying to push all the Metro Watch officers into a corner where they could barely do their job, as individuals that seemed to think they were above the help they hired, they acted like children, incapable of focusing on what was truly important and instead resorting to squabbling and deflecting the blame.
- one of the lead security officers is a documented issue, he is egotistical, aggressive, and is in no way qualified to be in leadership, let alone security, when working here, I heard from multiple sources that he was 'a black belt in Krav Maga or some other martial arts' and has military experience, and yet he'll cry wolf and blow any issue he has with other security officers out of proportion, the best days I worked at the hospital were the days he wasn't there, any lessons he may have learned in his military career obviously were never learned, or have been forgotten, and the security team is worse off with his involvement
- many security officers from Metro Watch had to be removed from the roster for PHSW specifically because of the fragile ego of the three stooges and any perceived slights recieved in their delusions,
- many issues with cameras, lighting and other hardware were documented during my time at Peace Health Southwest, and yet, despite their easy solution, nothing was ever done to address these issues, unless someone was about to get in trouble
- some of the medical staff, especially in ED/Triage would gossip about some of the Metro Watch officers that they did not care for, and in at least one instance stood by and watched as this officer struggled with an aggressive individual, despite requesting assistance

In short, the rank and file security officers and medical staff, for the most part, are good people, and when things go south, they'll back you up. Many times it was only myself, the ACA officer and Mobile 1 (shift lead) for the entire hospital, and when Code Greys and other issues arose that required standby, there were few moments that felt like I was out of my depth. That said, the security leadership at Peace Health Southwest is about as braindead as they can get, and do more to assuage their egos, than taking responsibility for the safety of the staff and patients. If things continue the way they were when I left, I would not be surprised to hear that things are even worse now.

review_title: PeaceHealth offers a rich working environment
pros:
1. Culture - The values of PeaceHealth are respect, stewardship, collaboration and social justice. During my 20 year career at PeaceHealth, I found these values to infuse the culture. It is a mission-driven organization, steeped in the calling to heal.
2. Pay and Benefits - Compensation is generous. And recently, PeaceHealth began offering a healthcare plan where employees and our families could receive care from PeaceHealth clinicians and at PeaceHealth facilities essentially without cost. 
3. Training and Tools -- During my employment, I was constantly learning and had access to the tools I needed. This support meant I was efficient and effective in my role. In addition, I have many transferrable skills for future jobs.
4. Location - The Pacific Northwest is a beautiful place to live and work. It offers enormous opportunities for an active lifestyle in a welcoming climate.
cons: Employee experiences across the organization vary widely. Some teams benefit from strong leadership, clear roles and a manageable workloads. Others are lacking in these areas.

review_title: The way I was treated, I should give it zero stars...
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Vancouver, WA
pros:
...but, it is just too good of a company to trash over the bad behavior of some corporate leaders and HR.
- The People - 99% of them walk the Mission of relieving pain and suffering, and treating people in a loving and caring way
- The Work - Supporting the manifestation of the Mission and implementation of the shared services just made me feel I had an important purpose each day
- The Facility - The catwalk!  Walking for meetings
cons:
Here we go.  When you walk in the building you will notice something odd.  There is not ONE wheelchair, walker, service animal, blindness cane... There are NO disabled people.  Well, I am disabled.  HR treated me like a pariah.  When I wrote my sixth email to HR asking for the chair and mat my doctor had recommended, I put a sentence in bold.  This email was put on my evaluation as a "scathing email" and as "poor behavior."  From that point on, I was treated differently.  It was a witch hunt to build a file of "errors" in my work.  Long story short, they got rid of their ADA problem and fired me for "poor performance."  (I have a 25-year career with positive references and client satisfaction.)

The building is not ADA-compliant, they do not hire people with disabilities, and I hope they get caught and held accountable for this, as it contradicts them as a faith-based healthcare organization.  The people reading this know who they are.  I hope the PeaceHealth EEOC department investigates them.

review_title: Stressful and under appreciated and insufficient staffing
pros: Wages and benefits better than retail or fast food
cons: Always short staffed. Everyone including housekeepers, supply staff, required to wear hospital supplied shrubs to give appearance of more nursing staff than is actually there. Patients are always confused about who are actually medical staff. To much bullying from peers and management and no place to turn to for help. Union is totally in bed with management unless you are medical staff (nurses, doctors). Need more local input in management and from staff actually working with patients and less time spent by managers and supervisors in meetings shuffleing papers and making graphs trying to figure out how to make more money instead of being concerned with what truly would be most beneficial to patients and allow all staff, not just medical staff, to properly do their jobs. less micro managing from out of town bean pushers trying to impress investors. The patients and the employees are both being short changed the way things are run now. When the newest top brass is more concerned with decorating the walls than making sure equipment, supplies and staff are sufficiently provided, something is seriously wrong.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Springfield, OR
pros: It's a job that pays well and offers decent benefits
cons:
Very clearly, staff satisfaction is not important to this company. It's all about budget, filling beds, medical treatment as fast as possible, sacrificing caregiver sanity, patient turnover, and redirecting budget deficit problems created by poor management and supervisor decisions, and instead, placing blame towards staff for accruing overtime because of attempting to meet constantly increasing unrealistic expectations. Declaring  'not for profit' is a joke. 
The constant need for travelers ought to say it all. Morale is in the basement. The hospital continually tries to do more with less, and complicated by union and contract verbiage, quality control in staffing expectations and/or accountability suffers tremendously. Patient centered care is not always in the forefront of caregiver prerogatives. 
Leadership responsible for steering policy and making business decisions are clearly not in touch with the reality of the unit(s), nor do they look for input or accurate feedback to the real struggles. 
LCC and PeaceHealth seem to almost have a  marriage where associate degree students/grads are taught by LCC alum, creating a very in-bred, bad habit driven and unhealthy micro-climate of nursing. Permanent employee recruitment is very narrow minded, and outside influence or perspectives seems to be frowned upon.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Springfield, OR
pros: Beautiful state of the art facility at Riverbend Hospital. Hardworking, dedicated care giving staff.  This is a closed house and has unions in place, thank god!
cons: We are chronically and dangerously understaffed most of the time due to draconian cuts to the frontline workers who do direct patient care.  They no longer seem to be focused on the original mission from when it was run by Catholic nuns.  Now it’s all about the bottom line.  On Riverbend’s recent 10 year anniversary, Peace Health sent out pink slips to caregivers in ICU, Medical ICU, Ward Clerks, Orderlies and Float Pool, due to many positions be eliminated.  They will be given the option of voluntary severance or bidding for open positions in other departments.  This is all part of their most recent “re-organization” which originally started with trying to push Nurses and CNA2 to 12 hour shifts.  Both unions fought back and now 12 hour shifts are voluntary for current staff.  I am most concerned about the elimination of the float pool.  That means caregivers will frequently float to all departments, including ones they might not be competent in.  It also means the floors may be left short staffed.  Over the last year, the shift I’ve worked on has been forced to care for 12+ patients due to shortages in staff.  It is very difficult to give good care under those circumstances.  It has become a hostile work environment.  Very unfortunate.

review_title: An amazing environment in which to work, but management needs work.
pros: The managers immediately above most entry- or medium-level jobs are amazing. I have never met so many people who are supportive of staff - whether in their own department or another - and quick to offer praise, congratulations or constructive criticism. The joke in most health care facilities is that the staff all drive somewhere else when they get sick, but in St. Joseph's, I would (and have) check in as a patient in a heartbeat.
cons:
The benefits aren't wonderful. Imaging, such as an MRI, is currently (as of January '09) covered at 80%... but an MRI can easily range $3500-5000. Prescription drug coverage is better, but you almost have to get everything through the mail from the Oregon pharmacy. All blood work and other diagnostic tests have to be ordered by your primary care physician, or else they're covered at a much lower rate.

Senior management - several levels above me - is not very good at communicating to the staff. Occasional memos regarding the economy pale in comparison to things like complete overhauls to training regimens that aren't communicated at all - until you need to request training.

pros: Security in opportunity for an Rn
cons: Transparency in top down leadership.

pros: Great pay, wonderful managers and coworkers
cons: Benefits could be more comprehensive

pros: good pay and great teamwork
cons: A frequent change in management

review_title: Pays great for cnas in area
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Eugene, OR
pros: Pays great for cnas in area
cons: Management isn’t the best at passing along messages and things aren’t always discussed when their are problems

pros: great pay and great people
cons: short staffed and over worked

job_title: Cath Lab Tech in Eugene, OR
pros: Coworkers are great. Variety of case types.
cons: Management takes away as much as they can.

pros: While a lot of the employees (caregivers) are overworked and tired, they don't let it show.  The people who work on the front lines are really good about keeping the patients front and center.  It was also nice to work for an organization that seemed to have their mission and values in front of them at all times as a guide.
cons: Way too much turnover in senior leadership.  They try to make it sound like they all chose to quit at once, but no one buys that.  The COO, Beth O'Brien, has brought in a huge number of consultants to run the hospitals and clinic operations which results in a lack of culture.  They are there for the short term to make changes happen, and then will be gone.  They are good at what they are there for, but it's like the place was acquired by another company who dropped their people in to take over.

pros: Benefits, culture, high quality care
cons: Nothing that I can think of

review_title: Was great... once upon a time
pros: Tenure based retirement matches. Pretty good health insurance. Some very competent colleagues.
cons: Not very competent management in IST from middle-management through senior leadership. Most of the people in power don't seem to have a vision for their business unit or at least one with a clear path to execution. Up through senior leadership, the buck doesn't seem to stop anywhere. A culture of "just doing what was told to me to do".

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Bellingham, WA
pros: Pay, coworkers, hours, docs, hours
cons: Have to use PTO for holidays

pros: There are some wonderful and caring Doctors and Caregivers.
cons: I have been with Peacehealth for 15+ years.  In the early days of my career Peacehealth was like family.  Going to work wasn't dreaded because you knew that your PH family was there to support you.  In recent years that "family" has been broken....Senior Leadership are rarely, very rarely seen out in the "trenches" really seeing what staff are up against with their daily work.  New processes are being developed without input or feedback from the staff that actually do the work.  Communication from the top down is non existant which doesn't help.  There are some employees left that have been there over the years that still are like family and will lend a supportive ear, but feel paralyzed to do much more due to our current Leadership.

review_title: Does not promote an environment of trust
pros: Largest employer in Longview Washington
cons: Constant state of job in security

review_title: They have no interest in keeping long time loyal employees!
job_title: Patient Financial Services in Bellingham, WA
pros: My co workers were the best part about working there.  Yet, you need to be careful about what you say, as I found some of the women there competitive, but in a very sneaky way.
cons:
I worked there for over five years, and had a spotless record.  When my department was relocated to Vancouver, WA there was no effort to try and retain me as a loyal employee.  I was laid off the day after my 5 year anniversary. 

I don't know of a single employee that was successfully transferred to another department.  

They have no interest in retaining good employees with longevity, because it's cheaper to hire someone who is not making the higher wage or has three weeks of vacation like myself.

review_title: Growing Pains, but the Caregivers here live by the mission
pros: The Caregivers are tired. They are also the most collegial bunch of people I've encountered. They will do the best with what they are given. They are an inquisitive and hardy bunch. Leadership team making strong efforts to keep staff afloat during a tumultuous time of transition and change in practices. The mission is strong. Leadership is making strides toward efficiency and explanation.
cons: Transparency is only beginning. The flip from top-down leadership to that of staff led practice and initiative is difficult, but not impossible-if the leadership team can remain stable. There is a sense of urgency due to the tumultuous changes in Healthcare (in general) and the need for process changes is high. This affects the translated transparency. There is a need for system-supported professional development that is not wholly union-based- classes for employees of all rank and leadership development is necessary. This said, it is difficult to pick the chicken or the egg, understood...but more support, education, communication, and understanding will be needed to succeed.

pros: People.  You can't beat the quality of people.  The pay is fair. Benefits are outstanding.  (PTO)  Nice location. Springfield Hospital is beautiful.  Depending on the department you are with, the advancement possibilities are good.  Also, depending on the department you would work in, I would recommend this as a great place.
cons: Communication from upper leadership (Vancouver WA)  We do not know in advance plans that effect families.  (Out sourcing, lay offs) Upper leadership fails to value front line employees. Cheap talk.  Little action.

job_title: Medical Lab Assistant in Springfield, OR
pros: Good coworkers, great leads, a manager who understands (even if upper management ignores them).
cons:
The Labs are completely ignored, especially if you're in Specimen Management. Upper management has to try and have their hands into everything- which is especially frustrating when they NEVER come to the lab! Several times so far this year, management has tried to make forceful changes to specimen management which would have caused harm to the entire department. It has required the entire department taking up arms together, writing long and detailed messages to the upper management about why the proposed changes WILL NOT WORK. All they seem to see is numbers on a screen, and they change procedures willy-nilly to keep clients happy. They seem to think it takes two weeks to train a new processor, which is DEAD wrong, especially when they keep making exceptions to standard procedures. You're looking at AT LEAST a six month training time before you're really qualified to train new processors. 

Also, the wages are poor. New processors make $0.50 less than someone who has worked there for OVER TEN YEARS!

review_title: Many preach mission and values, too few actually exhibit the behavior
pros: Competitive salary, some really good people work here, good benefit plans
cons:
Many have issues with responsibility and accountability, Some leaders have no business being in their positions and create toxic work environments. They hear what they want to hear. They  
spout out quotes and quips from the latest business books and are completely out of touch with reality. They have no idea how to manage staff or identify and rectify issues with employees. High turnover in leadership positions lately is "interesting" obvious political struggles in leadership are obvious to all employees with a brain.

pros: Coworker RNs were incredibly skilled and truly kind people.  I can't say enough about how hard they work to advocate and provide high quality care for patients despite being dangerously understaffed.
cons: One night I worked four hours with six patients and my CNA was assigned 18 patients.   Nurses are routinely floated to another floor after four hours and then have to return at the end of their shift to chart on the first four hours.  After being a nurse there I would never let a family member stay the night alone.  I know the nurses are working their hardest but as a nurse you don't even get a chance to look up your patients before you get report.  You come in early but still have to wait until the charge nurse finally makes the assignment.  I've worked in much safer facilities.  I wouldn't recommend working there unless you feel comfortable doing total care for six patients at one time because often that's just what ends up happening if you get a CNA who is completely overloaded or who doesn't want to do their job.   Despite unsafe staffing management required all staff to attend a four hour class on fall prevention.

pros: The people I work with  are talented professionals of the highest caliber. They devote themselves to providing the highest quality of care to their patients. They are thoughtful and kind, and are dedicated to giving their all 24/7,  365 days a year. I've worked with these people all hours of the day and night and would trust them with my life.
cons: The morale of the hospital has steadily declined over the past years as management and administration have slowly and steadily eroded the trust of their employees.  The emphasis has shifted to maintaining and improving the bottom line at the cost of taking care of the people who are on the front lines of healthcare.  Taking away PTO for overtime from ancillary staff is a prime example.

review_title: Unrealistic expectations put on too few employees
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Longview, WA
pros: There is a feeling of comraderee amongst employees. Most employees see patient care as a team effort. Vacation accruals are excellent from the start and increase the longer you are there.
cons: The CEO makes $1.27 million a year yet Peacehealth laid off 177 employees last year. Pay is not competitive and raises are not performance based with only a 2% raise for all employees for the last two years. A patient access representative starting pay is only $13.07 per hour while Kaiser starts at $17. Too many responsibilities are placed on each employee making it nearly impossible to achieve performance within the mission and values of the company.  Employees have to cut corners to get the job done and work through their breaks. But don't report not getting a break or you will be punished with a write up.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Longview, WA
pros: Knowledgeable staff, coworkers with great bed-side manors, people who care (for the most part) about the patients and the difference we can make as a whole. Great collaboration opportunities with other departments resulting in a knowledge and skillset of working with all kinds of people, disciplines and networks. Great for networking, great for the resume.
cons: Management has little control over the staff, gossiping is worse than at a high school, there is a major lack of consistency as well as just a lacking in general of disciplinary actions and major favoritism. Managers who are either related to some of their current employees, are best friends or roommates with their employees. High turnover rate. Hostile work environment.

review_title: Very challenging, poorly managed at upper leadership level.  Lots of turnover resulting from outsourcing of jobs.
job_title: Revenue Cycle Manager in Vancouver, WA
pros: Local employment opportunity without commuting to PDX.  Free parking.  Insurance benefits.  Nice workstation/office space environment.   On-site workout area/gym and locker rooms with showers.
cons: Current  upper leadership does not listen to caregivers concerns or suggestions. Targeting workforce for poor outcome statics resulting from decisions made by upper leadership team to implement applications/enhancements with minimal to no prior testing.  Toxic workplace environment... caregivers in fear of losing their jobs due to pattern of outsourcing of jobs.  Premature announcements to caregivers without workplan in place...leadership unable to answer/provide feedback to caregivers' questions.  Poorly managed office.

review_title: Poor communication - lower employees are disposable
pros: Pay is decent thanks to union.
cons: Mid to upper management is predominately male.  Lower employees feel unappreciated and any concerns are turned back on employee and no help is offered. Supervisors, leads, and managers speak down to lower employees and make them feel insignificant and stupid. Subtle threats, such as, 'Is this concern worth losing your job over?' Poor communication. Feels like employees are disposable. If you want to work less, your only option is to quit. No cutting back hours or call. It's all or nothing.  Unfortunately it is the only hospital in the Bellingham area, so no alternatives.  Thanks to the union the pay is decent, but it depends on how much do you need to make to overlook the disrespect and sexism that is so rampant in this organization?  Different expectations for different genders in same role.

review_title: In my personal experience, I was treated really well as an employee.
pros: I love my direct managers and HR Dept. There were a few times where the policies and staff really, truly saved me. Suggestions were always welcomed. Great benefits. Competitive pay. Welcoming staff. Wonderful place to learn new things. Respectable, established community asset. The resources are available to thrive happily here.
cons: Some Grumpy Gusses and resistance to change are peppered throughout. But if you can keep your glass half full, there are plenty of great, happy and inspirational people there. As far as a whole, I will say, there should be more of an effort to treat patients in a more integrated approach. There is a strong division of departments and the communication amongst them. Ultimately, it's the patients that suffer from it.

review_title: Not what it seems or should be.
pros: Decent benefits, good location and hours.
cons: High Stress, not good management

pros: Overall, PeaceHealth SWMC is a strong hospital with fabulous healthcare workers. There is great team work and camaraderie among the employees with a goal of high patient satisfaction.
cons: Upper management places unrealistic staffing expectations. Patient acuity levels are rising, the nurses are are continually asked to do more and more, but the staffing matrix is not adjusted accordingly. We are frequently asked to take more patients than the matrix lays out which equates to burned out workers and unsafe patient care.

job_title: MEDICAL Lab Technician in Ferndale, WA
pros: The laboratory is well run and organized. I have a great department manager who keeps things running smoothly.
cons:
PeaceHealth bought our lab a few years back. We were told by the CEO that things would stay"the same or better". Immediately after the change our overtime after eight hours was cut.
Our number of vacation days were cut as well. This is not "same or better". Health care requires an atmosphere of honesty, transparency and trust. These values have eroded over the past few years. Unionization has seemed to be the only way to guarantee that administration will treat us in a respectable manner.

review_title: Poor Management of Behavioral Health in Lane COunty
pros: They have a wide array of services and a nice facility.
cons: Behavioral health leadership has really went downhill this past couple years.  It feels like the compassion is gone and its all about business and numbers.  Especially in the inpatient unit "Johnson Unit", where they have taken a HUGE step backwards in care quality since changing leadership.  A lot of experienced mental health professionals have left and went to other agencies because of this.  If you want to work there,  I would suggest holding out and looking for a company with more of a an atmosphere of service.

review_title: Don't join the PeaceHealth Release of Information Department
job_title: Release If Information Specialist I in Vancouver, WA
pros: The mission of the organization is solid. Excellent first day orientation program. Solid benefits and PTO policy. The patients and other callers into the Department were very nice.
cons:
Terrible, degrading department training and evaluation. 

Prepare to be micromanaged within a millimeter of your life. If you are a robot and need to be told how to do every little thing, this job situation is for you. 

The phone training requires you to follow their poorly worded scripts verbatim or else you will be criticized and given a poor job evaluation.

review_title: Totally dysfuctional due to bad management
pros: Some really good imaging employees who are dedicated
cons: Failing system and management, can't trust management, too much call, don't expect to have a say on anything, your schedule will be changed constantly, schedule rarely accurate, tough to get time off,  expect to miss breaks and lunches, very inappropriate sexual comments made by manager to staff,  lack of honesty, morale problems, too much focus on the numbers and not the patients, bad decisions made by Vancouver that negatively affect patient care and employees, medical coverage is horrible, harassment, good old boys club mentality, some employees get away with not doing their job.  Don't expect HR or CEO to help with sexual harassment or stalker problems.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Bellingham, WA
pros:
I felt very fortunate to be given the opportunity to work at Peace Health. I was applying online for about a year, but with no hospital experience there was no consideration in my applications. The company had a hiring even that i decided to go to and ended up getting hired! I was so excited for the opportunity that I thought was impossible without experience. So far, the hiring process, skype training and floor experience has been very smooth! My manager has been very personable and willing to work around my schedule with consideration. I have been very pleased and excited to work for this company. 
I enjoy that there are online/system learning resources for careconnect to browse through for when I have questions and/or having nothing else to do.
cons: Managers no where on sight to help, but can be reached by phone

pros: Good benefits package including retirement, generous paid time off.  Fair wages.  Conscientious staff. Beautiful facility.  Company encourages and assists with continuing education.
cons: Top management is unstable, constantly changing hands.  There is a very political atmosphere of disrespect and attempts to control by spinning information are common.  Contract negotiations are particularly contentious. If you can focus on the basics of the job and your immediate environment it is  not unpleasant.  However, if this sort of thing gets to you, they are not for you.

pros: I have such nice coworkers and the people I work with in other departments are outstanding, too. Smart and caring, great combo. I have worked for previous companies that tolerated a hostile work environment and that is not the case here in our corporate office, in my opinion. We have work/life balance, and seems like corporate restructuring dust has settled. I feel optimistic about the company's future.
cons: We have had a lot of leadership changes, particularly at the executive level, without a lot of explanation staff as to why. But I think this is pretty standard in the corporate world.

pros:
Lots of job postings in all locations
Wages are listed
cons: it takes MONTHS to hear anything from HR.  Even if you email them, they don't reply.  You have to know 2-3 months in advance that you'd like to work there before you apply, it takes THAT LONG.  Why???

pros: Great people to work with. Better paying salaries than most companies in town. Peacehealth really acknowledges your personal life as very important, and they don't discourage family and personal events at all. This part is great! Very involved with community and does a lot of charitable work. Established non-profit.
cons: Hard to get changes made due to the large organizational structure, too many executive changes in short amount of time.  Seems like a lot of money for lab work and doctor visits using our employee healthcare and going to our own physicians ... But I'm sure this is still better than most other companies.

review_title: Great people but poor vision of the future
job_title: Senior Applications Analyst in Vancouver, WA
pros: Very bright, hardworking, knowledgeable people. Maintaining lots of continued friendships with knowledge sharing. Decent benefits offered. Nice locations and pleasant surroundings.
cons: Poor vision for the future of healthcare. PeaceHealth is spending millions of dollars installing all new computer systems to meet new regulatory requirements yet unwilling to modernize with new processes and workflow redesign.  The new systems are being molded and forced to allow providers to use existing workflows.

job_title: Senior Marketing Communications Project Specialist in Springfield, OR
pros: Great benefits and wonderful people to work with. It's rewarding when you can see how your work makes a positive difference in the lives of patients.
cons: Lots of leadership changes and a general lack of direction. The company changed quite a bit in the six years I worked there. The company used to really care about employees and most felt they were not just a number, but as health care has changed, so has PeaceHealth. I survived many layoffs and reductions in force. On the other side of all that PeaceHealth emerged as a much more corporate company. Very little power to make change in local markets or customize services to meet the needs of individual communities.

review_title: Rather stressful, but rewarding and challenging work
pros: The staff I work with in Home Health services seem so supportive, almost like family. Flexible schedule, and benefits available, though pro-rated with a 20 hour position. Good job security, decent pay and benefits.
cons: Too much top heavy administration. Superfluous expenditures such as excessive use of video which actually takes more time away from our work. Not enough support for professional development, use of awkward difficult to use software. Many changes continue, not always for the better, seem aimed more at  money for the business than for supporting field staff.

review_title: Intensive care RN who loves PeaceHealth
pros: As a recent new grad who was welcomed into the new grad residency program, I am amazed at the level of eduation I am recieving.  My preceptor is incredible and I truly feel I have the support from all around me from the CNA's to management.
cons: The computer system is quite slow despite a recent upgrade. There is the potential for a lot of time wasted.  Learning to click on the computer, doing pt care, going back and clicking 3/4 more times with the hope it is loaded by the time you're done with said pt.  has helped me reduce time waste.  Solving the network/computer speeds would be tremendously productive.

review_title: Geeat Place to Work If You Like Being Treated Like a Child
pros: Good health benefits if you use PeaceHealth providers and facilities; great co-workers.
cons: Extremely poor and unprofessional leadership in patient financial services; they micromanage you to death and have unrealistic expectations of all the staff, mostly due to their own failed decisions.  It is not uncommon to have so many people leaving that the place is like a revolving door.  I started a position in customer service and left within six months as it was literally the worst environment I have ever worked in anywhere.

pros: PeaceHealth has been a good place to work for most of my career.  I have been able to grow in my knowledge and experiences.  I've always felt it was my calling to work here.
cons: We have had a lot of leadership turnover, and fundamental change in priorities due to the changing healthcare paradigms.  Leadership has not provided solid direction in recent years, so the ship is sailing without a rudder.  Unfortunately, we are burning a lot of money on consultants that are not providing the value I would expect.

pros: I have been an occupational therapist for many years and worked in a lot of different places, most recently the VA for the past 10 years. PeaceHealth is by far one of the best companies I have ever worked for. The orientation focused on  employees being "caregivers" not just staff , and  the the mission statement  is  heartfelt and compassionate Their wages are very competitive and I feel respected, valued, and supported by my supervisor and team. It's only been a couple of months but unless things change, I hope to be working there for years to come
cons: The computer system (EPIC) is laborious and  difficult to learn...too many drop down options and information to wade through.

pros: It is impossible to be fired.  People have been filling IT roles for decades with essentially no practical knowledge of programming or design.
cons: It is hard to convey how truly awful PeaceHealth is.  Your ability to navigate dozens of conflicting personal agendas will far outweigh competence in predicting your success.  The fact that management are clueless would not be so intolerable if it were not accompanied by dishonesty and mean spirited tactics.  To make matters worse, it is all done with the premise that they are carrying on the mission of Jesus Christ.

review_title: Per-Diem Radiologic Technologist - St. John - Longview, WA
pros: The radiology dept is comprised of one of the most friendly and helpful group of techs  and management I've ever worked with.  I credit the radiology supervisor and lead tech for their ability recognize a candidate that would be a good fit in their department because, I do feel very comfortable working here; and I've work in a lot of different x-ray departments - in Portland, California and New Orleans.
cons: Learning to navigate within the EPIC, Synapes computer applications takes some time as it is not very intuitive and requires lots of memorization. Commuting to Longview from uptown Portland adds 2 .5 hours to my work day but, for me it hasn't been too bad.

review_title: PeaceHealth is doing a lot of things right
pros: Satisfying work, attention to the "mission" of caring for the disadvantaged. Good benefits that include the option of adding health insurance for a"significant other" be it an elderly parent, disabled adult child, or domestic partner. Eugene is also a great place to live.
cons: Layers of middle management that sometimes seem to focus on procedural issues to the detriment of the day to day functioning. Our department seems to go through a manager a year. The ones that seemed to work effectively on department issues ran into difficulty in the hierarchy.

review_title: Trauma II hospital with great staff, never a dull moment
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Vancouver, WA
pros:
Fast paced work environment on Ortho/Neuro/Trauma floor 
Regionally ranked #10 in WA state and #5 in the Portland, OR metro area
Excellent staff members who advocate for their patients
Beautiful new hospital wing opened up recently in the Firstenburg Tower
cons:
Floors will see very high volume patients with low ratio for staffing at times
Burnout rate is high due to constant added features to charting
Under-utilization of some ancillary departments on floors (i.e. respiratory therapist should be embedded more into patient-care for med-surg and surgical floors, and not just in critical and emergency care settings)

review_title: Watch your back, stay on guard
pros: Location and all the doctors were great to work with.
cons: First clinic for 3 years was great. Transferred and what a mistake that was.  If you want to watch your back all the time, be treated like a child and with no respect, this place is for you! Watched other MA's  mock patients, informed manager who did nothing. Very disturbing and uncomfortable environment to work in.

review_title: Culture Change - not for the better
pros: Caring, long tenured line staff and line managers.  Many mission-driven aspects of the work.  Recent changes have degraded both of these positives substantially, however.
cons: A distinct shift to focus on short-term planning, versus long-term strategies that play out in the market.  Huge sunk costs in HIT tossed aside for the newest shiny object demonstrates poor planning and vision by senior leaders.  Pay lower than average for the region.  Unable to compete with larger IDNs, and not able to close the deal to become a larger group themselves

pros: I really enjoyed the people I worked with.
cons:
Senior management does not lead.  They talk about culture change and their plans and then they disappear.  If this organization is going to succeed with their culture change they need to have leaders that are willing to get in the weeds, preach it, and break down the silo's that have been created over the years.  They also need to hold those that are not on-board accountable.

Health insurance is below average.

Lack of family planning services at their hospitals and clinics.  I realize that this is a not-for-profit Catholic organization, but they receive Federal Tax dollars and therefore should be required to provide family planning.

pros: Good salary and benefits. Good analysts and immediate IT supervisors.
cons: Poor senior management.  Outmatched operational directors and managers.  Mass exodus of top notch talent and inability to recruit and retain high integrity people.  No support from within IT management, you are subject to the whims and insecurities of operations.  Those people live in fear for their jobs and pass that same fear and insecurity down the chain.  This company will probably fail on its own and be acquired by bigger, more professional company with better integrity.

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Vancouver, WA
pros: Not many.  I did meet 3 people I would consider friends and continue to talk too outside work.  Other then that, there is really nothing good to say.
cons: Management doesn't manage.  The Respiratory Department is ran by the staff, not the manager.  Unfortunately the staff running the place have their own agendas.  They will lie and attempt to ruin long, good standing reputation's.  If you have experience and your looking for a new place to work, keep looking.  Peace health Southwest Medical Center is not worth the risk to your reputation.

pros: Great supervisors and managers. They give you helpful feedback. Providers respect you. They genuinely care about their staff.
cons: Pay is less than other parts of the country. Benefits seem to be getting cut back each year.  Differential pay is much less than other parts of the country.  HR does not seem to want to be involved with communicating changes with staff. The company overworks management to the extent that management doesn't get time to interact with staff as much as they would like.

review_title: If I could rate Leadership less than a single star...
pros: There are well intending and immensely intelligent people that work here. Unfortunately there is a sense of continuing poor financial performance, difficultly in retaining and acquiring talent which leads to overworked and unsupported staff from current COO.
cons:
Abusive, unfounded aggressive tactics by PMO leadership that is condoned by HR leadership and/or  COO executive staff continues to protect employee(s). Even though the behaviors contradict Mission values and statement.
PeaceHealth leadership does not walk the walk.

pros: I like the mission and values of peacehealth.  I  like that it is a  Non profit. I like that it is also Christien based.
cons: They are outsourcing a lot of departments which is horrible. Many people are losing there job or are being asked to apply with the new company that they outs outsourced to for way less pay. I do not want to do the same job for less pay. Even though I have been there 10 years they are hiring everyone at entry levels.

pros: Liked Coworkers for most part.
cons: Lots of Big Fish in small pond mentalities. People in leadership positions without education or management skills. When suggesting changes or improvement there was a lot of "Why change, this is the way we've always done it"., type attitude. Professionalism here wouldn't past muster in other states.

pros: Love my co-workers and the mission of the company for what it means.
cons:
Fast turnover of administrative leaders. No continuity.
Poor communication between admin and staff in charge of patient care.
Poor delivery of tools for work (EHR for example) making it hard to finish your work n a timely manner. Demands for productivity are increased nevertheless, which makes your feel like the "want great productivity, but give you poorly polish tools to achieve it". At least the salaries got better recently.
If you look for life/work balance don't work for PH.

review_title: Wonderful mission, a company in the midst of transition
pros: Pay is very competitive in the local market,  great teamwork in my department and other departments, focus is on patient care, management listens to caregivers
cons: There is a lot of change happening right now as Peacehealth continues to transition from a holding company to an operating company, this should have happened at least 15 years ago, so there is lots of catch up going on.  Operations needs to become more efficient and modern and caregivers need to adjust and not stay stuck in the 80's.

review_title: Don't feel that employee's are valued
pros: Love the nursing staff, dr's, and all other employees that work hard every day!
cons: Even though there are wonderful people that work there, on the nursing units there is a negative attitude and low morale.

review_title: Hospital's heart is in the right place, but processes could stand improvement.
pros: From the first day I started work I felt that the people I worked with were both professional and human and willing to engage both in their jobs. I was expected to perform my job and reminded if I made mistakes, while simultaneously reminded that I was still new and mistakes were expected. As I grew into my position, my immediate superiors allowed me to expand my own sphere of responsibility within my department and take on new projects as I saw fit. As an aside, if you are covered under the contract (an RN), you have a number of unique benefits, including guaranteed annual raises, seniority and rules governing how (and how often) the hospital can call you in or send you home.
cons: They are short staffed at the time of this review on the clinical side of operations, which creates tension between the nursing staff (RNs, LPNs, and CNAs) and the administration. Nurses feel things need to change, and while management says they are working on plans for change, we only hear about them randomly - usually in response to a direct question from a staff member to an administrator. There is very little top-down communication to the staff letting them know that their concerns are valid and what, if any, ideas are being formulated. This appears to be systemic or process-related as individual administrators I've spoken with are generally very forthcoming with information and express genuine concern for the situation. As an organization, however, they have failed to make any such comments to the staff, leaving many of them (some who have been there for 25 years or more) feeling out of the loop and unvalued.

pros: The caregivers were hard working and great to work with.  The schedule was flexible and managable.
cons: Management was over-whelmed by directives coming down from the top.  Manager avoided confrontation with employees by not dealing with it and therefore encourging bad behavior.  She also doesn't agree with upper management and is subversively undermining them when she can.

pros: After putting in several years the Paid Time Off is not bad. The 403b match is pretty good, 3% and they do allow you to hold more pretax up to 10%. PeaceHealth does hire good people so your coworkers are likely to be good to work with. Overall it's is a good place to work.
cons: Due to rising costs to provide healthcare, they have to look at ways to save money such as cut staff, not fill positions, and cut employee benefits.

pros:
I have been with PeaceHealth for about 3 weeks now an I am so impressed. It is clear this company truly cares about its employees.  (Well, actually we're called caregivers not employees. Even those of us who don't treat patients. How cool is that?!)  The culture here is such a welcome change from my previous employer in corporate America.  I feel like this is a place where I matter as an individual and where I can make a difference at work and I my community.  

The health benefits here are drastically better than what I'm used to. They pay 100% of employee and a good portion of dependents on their high deductible plan. And even the low deductible plan is very affordable for employees and dependents.  

Starting vacation is good. Since they have many employees that work on holidays, everyone uses PTO for holidays AND vacation.  But, you earn enough to get around 3 weeks even after taking time off for the standard holidays.
cons:
The life insurance amounts available for voluntary purchase aren't as high as I'm used to. And, the amount you can purchase for your spouse is much lower than I would like.  
Also, you do not have the option to purchase spouse disability insurance.  
They do not offer a PTO/vacation buy program that many employers offer. 
Unlike many large companies where you are eligible for benefits at date of hire, your benefits are not available until 30 days after the first 1st of the month after you start. 
Although the retirement contribution is above industry standard after you've been here for many years, the initial matching amounts in your early years of employment are very low.

review_title: Compassionate Care....unless you're employed by them
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Bellingham, WA
pros: PeaceHealth is the only hospital in Bellingham.  If you are dedicated to excellent, inpatient care....as an employee PeaceHealth is your only option.
cons: PeaceHealth promises compassionate care.  That promise falls short of the employees and dedicated care givers.  They have a hypocritical claim of being a Christian Health System, yet their treatment of their employees is most certainly not Christian.  They have gone through many 'rounds' of layoffs over the past five years.  They promise 'safety to speak up' though have seen this, personally, fall short again and again.  They are unable to successfully negotiate union contracts and often works and administration are at odds over fair and safe work practices.

pros: Comparable pay with benefits.  Small community with great staff and Doctors.  Flexible  scheduling for students.  Tuition re-imbursement for those who will continue employement for at least one year after payment.
cons: non-flexible shifts of 12* days/nights (there are not 8/10* shifts for medical floor nurses).  No onsite childcare.

pros:
From the start during the selection process to now when I’m at the end of my first month, I’m very impressed with everyone I’ve met or dealt with. Timely, clear and professional communications, and very organized. 
I was also nicely surprised with their total compensation package which acknowledged my years of experience. I didn’t accept the job due to pay & benefits, so it was “icing on the cake.”
cons: I have not witnessed any “cons.”

review_title: Recent policy changes are riddled with unrealistic expectations.
pros: Amazing providers, great place to work if you don’t have kids/family. Benefits ok.
cons: No work/life balance. You have a 7 minute window to clock in but if you’re one minute late, it’s a count against you. But you’re scolded with overtime. If you have an appointment or child sick during your scheduled shift, no matter how many hours you work, PTO is taken. Management doesn’t listen to their employees no matter what they say and they will tell you they do. No flexing on those slower days. Pay is mediocre. You can make more pretty much anywhere else. Policies before employees and patient safety. Employee beware.

review_title: Not the company it once was
pros: Most of the staff try to do their very best, even though they are unappreciated by upper management.  Retirement plan is good.
cons: Upper management either not qualified or indifferent to the challenges of those providing direct patient care. The corporate mission of treating everyone in a loving and caring way does not extend to it's own employees. I have worked here for nearly 30 years, and it is most assuredly not the place it once was.

review_title: Not the organization it to be...
pros: The people: the staff, our doctors, and other providers genuinely had a heart for those they served.
cons: After the merger with PeaceHealth, the organization seemed to no longer provide the support,  stability, resources, or pay the employees need to stay invested in the company.

pros: Decent pay, hours are good, super benefits,
cons: Some Rude unfriendly staff.  That's about the only complaint I have so far. I've only worked at peace Health for a short time.

pros:
Great clinical bedside staff
Beautiful location
cons:
Horrible administration
Can't keep managers
If a manager actually wants to manage and has an opinion different than wat administration wants they find a way to make them "resign".
Never have enough money to get more staff or equipment but then report record profits

review_title: I worked for PeaceHealth full time for ten years.
job_title: Billing, Coding and Patient Financial Service in Bellingham, WA
pros: The first five years were wonderful. I worked in a small location away from the hospital. I loved going to work each day.
cons: Out sourcing, position eliminations, consolidation to Longview. Favoritism by management, bullying by staff and management. HR ignores complaints and believes management only. Unreasonable work load, lower pay and no raises for several years. Corporate attitude no longer patient centered care.

pros: I worked at the corporate HQ. The people there are some of the friendliest I've worked with. PTO and benefits package were competitive with two health coverage plans to choose from. There is an onsite cafeteria and gym.
cons:
Ultimately the lack of high-performing co-workers is what drove me to seek other options. My department leaders failed to set strategic goals and hold people accountable for results. I found they were disconnected with industry best practices based on their decisions to partner with certain vendors. There is a general lack of momentum to achieve anything. Most people who work here value stability, reliability and work-life balance. Projects move slow and the culture is a cautious one.

It's not a bad company. I was rarely ever stressed out. I had been working insane hours in a previous company and was ready for a break when I came to PH. My job was easy and the expectations were low, so I thought I'd use the opportunity to get a lot of projects done in my personal life. Fast forward one year: I hadn't accomplished much and the general feeling of malaise that presided over me at work bled into my personal life. I was really depressed. Thankfully I've found a balance with my new company. I learned a lot and am grateful for my time there but I didn't see a future with this company.

review_title: It’s not all about money and numbers
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Vancouver, WA
pros:
Good PTO accrual 
Good Benefits
cons:
Depends on your unit- but sometimes awful managers.
When I was resource/float pool in Vancouver, they treated floats like crap. 
I transferred from Bellingham to Vancouver- my pay dropped due to “union” change and HR didn’t see an issue.
Significant amounts of favoritism. 
Also trying to transfer from one Peacehealth to another was incredibly difficult.

pros: Co-workers are a good group of people
cons: Inflexibility.  The atmosphere is one of 'you should be happy we even hired you'.  They do not go out of their way for their employees in any manner.  Rigid.  Communication is poor.  Sorry I signed on and will not persue other positions.

pros:
Opportunity to work in healthcare
Most employees great to work with
Desirable employee benefit packages
cons:
Highly toxic work environment
Senior leaders totally out of touch
Top down leadership style stifles innovation and muffles any critical feedback of leadership decisions. Employee engagement surveys structured to avoid critical comments about leadership.
Salaried employees expected to work extensive overtime with no compensation

pros: Pay is good and actual peer coworkers are typically pretty cohesive
cons: Absolutely horrific management (mostly in the higher ranks). The complete tunnel vision on quality assurance/money they can make, is disheartening. Our patient satisfaction is secondary to profit. They employ WAY fewer people than are needed (or safe!), and require them to do the work of 2-3 people. The employees are completely expendable to them. Unsafe environment for employees, and VERY difficult to report a provider for Medicare fraud. Absolute worst hospital I’ve ever worked for!

review_title: High Acuity RN, loving the PeaceHealth Culture of Caring
pros:

Collegial atmosphere
Great benefits

Responsive, supportive management
Evidence based clinical support and guidelines
Culture that values evidence based care
Pursuing Magnet status
Strong community that comes through in times of need for patients and each other

pros: Great team in our department.  Competitive salary for some employees, Career opportunities are available.
cons: Not for profit healthcare in difficult situation to compete in today's market. Some employees feel under appreciated by administration.  Current frustrations with union negotiations.

pros: Great salary.  Nurses are treated with respect.  The work environment is safe and enjoyable. Patient care is not a buzzword, but a real focus for this company.
cons: There are no serious cons to working at PeaceHealth.  The community it is in is hard hit in the recession so employment for spouses is scarce.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Deer Island, OR
pros: Anonymity, I get to work when and where I want, because nobody knows what is going on.
cons: I really wanted this company to excel in the Northwest Market and maybe they will in the end, but the lack of communication and mass exodus from PeaceHealth is too much for me to stick around for.

review_title: It was like stepping back in time.
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Longview, WA
pros: I quit after 30 days.
cons: This company seems oblivious to basic human dignity. Don't expect ethical codes of conduct promoting social equality within the workplace that lead to respect and fulfillment for all employees. The "tone form the top" is malicious and petty - beginning with the stereotypical arrogant and aloof, elitist physicians, to the frustrated ill -fated bitter nursing staff who must have realized early on in their careers that compassionate nursing was not their true calling. Expect rudeness, pettiness and a whole lot of ego - if the work of saving lives weren't so serious the whole matter would be laughable.

pros: Doctors are a wonderful group to work for.
cons: Just as any place of employment, there needs to be accountability put in place for each employee.

review_title: Great Organization Culture and Core Values

My salary here is well below the market price for the Portland market but I’m happy here.  I haven't had the feeling of looking forward to go to work eveyday for a longtime until now.
cons: I couldnt think of any Cons here at Peacehealth to be honest.

review_title: Mission was great, but changes were challenging
pros: I loved the folks I worked with in Bellingham. People there were really nice and people cared about each other.
cons: Changes in health care in a college, under-employed town were extremely challenging. It brought stress and morale down. I did experience favoritism and it was frustrating to see the mananger do that, when she knew it wasn't ethical.

pros: It is a place full of caring nurses, doctors and professionals who give their all to make patient outcomes and experience better.  Couldn't ask for better colleagues
cons: The management at the top levels over the past 5-7 years has created mass disengagement and issues related to how change is rolled out, and how the company is being organized.  Their values and their actions are not aligned

pros: Good staff to work with. Followed protocols put in place by Joint commission. Good patient care
cons: Community hospital that Merged with PeaceHealth. Didn't know direction it was going. Had 2 sets of CNO and CEO fired within 2 years of working there. And a 3rd set fired within 3 months of leaving facility. Very chaotic for managers attempting to follow directives when they changed every couple of months.

pros: Decent pay, decent benefits. There's a good variety of shifts to work. I can't think of very many pros. Most of the employees are cohesive.
cons: Upper management does not value the opinion of the nurses. They institute major changes in patient care areas without input from nurses. They are a non profit that acts like a for profit. They do not value their employees, they treat them like they're easily replaceable.

job_title: RN Registered Nurse in Bellingham, WA
pros: This is the only hospital in Whatcom County.

Management blatantly disregards the union contract, and if someone files a grievance, they harass and intimidate the nurse. Peacehealth has no competition in Whatcom County, and they believe it give them the permission to treat employees like crap. If you want to be treated like a human, move south where more employment opportunities, and you will be treated with respect.

I genuinely believe PeaceHealth wants to provide compassionate care to people of all socioeconomic and ethnic backgrounds and do it the best it can.
cons: I would have liked to do training strictly at riverbend rather than the university district campus. The UD campus was confusing and it was easy to get lost.

pros: great people to work with.All want to do the best job with limited resources of time and coworkers
cons: Middle management hardly there too many layers of responsibilities that they don't know what is really happening in their various units.Everything communicated by email but you can't see it at home so if you are gone seems like hundreds of emails waiting once back at work.

pros: Team environment among co-workers, passion for excellence among our healthcare staff and a great commute that doesn’t involve crossing a bridge.
cons:
Mgmt does not reflect company mission statement.  “Reflections” are read to start every meeting, supposedly meant to inspire, but are forgotten once the words are read aloud.  Do good, be present and respect others, are only tag lines used in upper mgmt.  
Integrity is a foreign concept in the HR dept

I feel I am a valued employee all day. It's a joy to come to work every day.
cons: Nothing that I can think of at this time.

review_title: Either be related to someone or bring kneepads

Health insurance is bare minimum. The big business of Peace Health is to expand geographically, and the bottom line is making more money.

job_title: IS Business Analyst in Sedro-Woolley, WA

cons: Small hospital incorporated into a large healthcare organization spanning from Alaska to Oregon. Changes take time to implement. Less resources available in comparison to larger facilities. Frustrated staff make the work environment uncomfortable at times.

review_title: Worst place ever to work for
pros: Good vacation pay... nice employees /co workers..
cons: The food sucks... mostly old.. the hospital went to crap after peacehealth took over.. environmental services is the cleaning portion of the hospital. . I didnt get any help from L&i because they way they did paperwork... said it happen in the family birth center at clark college. .in vancouver... at 1am... I have never seen a class at a college let alone someone in a vacant class at 1am... they lie about alot.. they screw their employees. . They black ball employees from getting other jobs that pay better in other departments even though you get degrees or certifications.. the benifits suck.. they have the cities in their back pocket where they are located.... I used to love my job there.. but after all the negative that I saw and no help from the state even with legal proof and documentation. .. my advice.. go somewhere else...... if people remember... this is part of the reason peacehealth lost the kaiser contract to legacy.. they had the contract for 13 years.. lost it 6 months after peacehealth took over... also.. with lay offs... its funny.. the ceo makes over a million a year.took a pay cut for 60k a year... dont forget your oil change on your yellow lamborghini joe... they have acting directors from multiple states flying in and out weekely.. people wonder why 170 plus got laid off within a week

cons: None. I really liked it there. The only reason I left was because the company relocated out of the Seattle area, and I did not want to move.

pros: PeaceHealth pays well. Regular market adjustments are nice.

pros: Fun, challenging. Everyone I’ve worked with have always been helpful and don’t make you feel bad for asking questions or needing help

pros: Love working with patients and being an advocate. Coordinate care is inportant .  Working with providers and obtaining a trusting relationship
